summary: T-Mobile's Law Enforcement Relations department objects to a legal demand for subscriber information and call detail records, citing various procedural and practical reasons, including data retention policies for Metro by T-Mobile subscribers.

events.title: T-Mobile Files Objection to Legal Demand
events.description: T-Mobile formally objects to a legal demand for subscriber information and call detail records, citing failure of personal service, lack of jurisdiction, facial invalidity, overbreadth, insufficient response time, inaccessible records, or records not maintained by T-Mobile.

locations.description: Address for T-Mobile Law Enforcement Relations

keyFacts: T-Mobile objected to a legal demand on August 8, 2021, citing multiple procedural and substantive grounds.
Subscriber information for Metro by T-Mobile branded subscribers is retained for approximately six months after account termination.
Call detail records for Metro by T-Mobile subscribers are stored and maintained for up to two years.
The document indicates a legal demand was made for records that T-Mobile may not have been able to fully provide due to data retention policies.
